review.title: Identifying Dogmatism in Social Media: Signals and Models
review.abstract: We explore linguistic and behavioral features of dogmatism in social media and construct statistical models that can identify dogmatic comments. Our model is based on a corpus of Reddit posts, collected across a diverse set of conversational topics and annotated via paid crowdsourcing. We operationalize key aspects of dogmatism described by existing psychology theories (such as over-confidence), finding they have predictive power. We also find evidence for new signals of dogmatism, such as the tendency of dogmatic posts to refrain from signaling cognitive processes. When we use our predictive model to analyze millions of other Reddit posts, we find evidence that suggests dogmatism is a deeper personality trait, present for dogmatic users across many different domains, and that users who engage on dogmatic comments tend to show increases in dogmatic posts themselves.

Which user is more dogmatic in the above examples? This question is simple for humans. Phrases such as "they think" and "theories don't even understand," suggest an inconsistency of opinion, while "I think" and "win-win" suggest the opposite. Can we educate computers to make similar psychology distinctions in the work?

sections.heading: 2 Dogmatism data
sections.text: The contributions to Reddit capture and discussion require a variety of training data, which makes them a natural starting point for untangling domain-independent linguistic features of dogmatism. Subreddits are sub-communities on Reddit that are oriented toward specific interests or topics, such as technology or politics. Sampling Reddit as a whole would distort the model in terms of the most frequently discussed content. However, by sampling posts from individual subreddits we can control the types of posts we use to train our model. To collect a variety of training data, we randomly analyzed 1,000 posts from the fields of politics, business, science, and AskReddit, and 1,000 additional posts from the Reddit front page. All posts in our sample appeared between January 2007 and March 2015 and included between 300 and 400 characters to control length effects.

sections.heading: 4 Predicting dogmatism
sections.text: We will now show how to use the linguistic characteristics we have described to create a classification that predicts dogmatism in comments. A predictive model further validates our characteristics and allows us to analyze dogmatism in millions of other Reddit comments in a scalable manner, with multiple uses in ongoing, downstream analyses. Our goal is to (1) understand how well we can use the strategies in Section 3 to predict dogmatism, and (2) test the domain independence of these strategies. First, we will test the performance of our model under cross-validation within the Reddit comment set. We will then evaluate the Reddit-based model based on a held corpus of New York Times comments that is commented on with the technique in Section 2. We will not refer to these second sets of data during feature construction. To classify, we will consider two classes of comments: non-dogmatic and non-dogmatic.

sections.heading: 5 Dogmatism in the Reddit Community
sections.text: We now apply our dogmatism classifier to a larger set of posts and examine how dogmatic language shapes the Reddit community. Specifically, we apply the BOW + LING model, which has been trained on the full Reddit dataset, to millions of new uncommented posts, marking these posts with a probability of dogmatism according to the classifier (0 = undogmatic, 1 = dogmatic), and then using these dogmatism annotations to answer four research questions.

sections.heading: 5.1 What subreddits have the highest and lowest levels of dogmatism? (R1)
sections.text: A natural starting point for analyzing dogmatism on Reddit is to examine how it characterizes the sub-communities of the site. To answer this question, we sampled 1.6 million posts from the entire Reddit community between 2007 and 2015. We then comment on each of these posts with dogmatism using our classifier and calculate the average dogmatism level for each subreddit in the sample of at least 100 posts. We present the results of this analysis in Table 3. The subreddits with the highest dogmatism levels tend to be oriented toward politics and religion (DebateAChristian or ukpolitics), while those with the lowest levels tend to focus on hobbies (photography or homebrawing). sections.heading: 5.3 What user behaviors are predictive of dogmatism? (R3)
sections.text: We have shown that dogmatism is captured by many linguistic features, but can we detect other high-level user behaviors that are similarly predictable? To find out, we calculate using the data sample of 1000 users and 10 million posts described in Section 5.2. Specifically, we calculate (1) activity: the total number of posts a user makes, (2) breadth: the number of posts a user posts in a discussion, (3) focus: the percentage of a user's posts appearing in the subreddit in which he is most active, and (4) engagement: the average number of posts a user contributes to each discussion in which he is engaged. We then adapt these behavioral features to a linear regression model in which we predict the average dogmatism level of each user. sections.heading: 5.4 How does dogmatism impact a conversation? (R4)
sections.text: How does the interaction with a dogmatic comment affect a conversation? Can users shrug it off? Or do otherwise non-dogmatic users themselves become more dogmatic? To answer this question, sample 600,000 conversations from Reddit. These conversations consist of two people (A and B) talking to each other, with the structure: A1 → B → A2. This allows us to measure the influence of B's dogmatism on the response of A while simultaneously predicting the dogmatism response of A2. If B's dogmatism has no effect on the response of A, we model the influence of dogmatism on these conversations through linear regression. This model incorporates two features, the dogmatism levels of A1 and B, and predicts the dogmatism response of A2. If B's dogmatism has no effect on the response of A, the coefficient corresponding to B will have no significance in the model.

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: Contrary to the mathematical models we have presented, dogmatism in psychology is usually measured by survey measures in which study participants answer questions that reveal underlying personality traits (Rokeach, 1954). Over time, these surveys have been updated (Shearman and Levine, 2006) and improved to meet standards of psychometric validity (Crowson, 2009).These surveys are often used to investigate the relationship between dogmatism and other psychological phenomena (Martin et al., 2011), even dogmatic people tend to exhibit an increased propensity for confrontation (ElNawawy and Powers, 2010) or moral beliefs and religiosity (Swink, 2011), and a lower probability of cognitive flexibility (Martin et al., 2011), even among stereotypically non-dogmatic groups such as atheists (Gurney et al, 2013).

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: We have compiled the first corpus of social media posts commented on with dogmatism scores, which allows us to explore linguistic characteristics of dogmatism and develop a predictive model that analyzes new content. We apply this model on Reddit, where we discover behavioral predictors of dogmatism and current patterns in the comments of dogmatic users. Could we use this computational model to help users shed their dogmatic beliefs?
